scenario_0.summary: In a peak-period warehouse cycle, two workers perform a combined replenishment and inbound sorting operation. Both workers alternate and share tasks of sorting newly arrived items placed on Large Shelf 4 and Area 5. They shuttle inventory along the robot's fixed route from M21 to E14, performing concurrent sorting and replenishing on Shelf 2 and Shelf 3. Their natural workflows require frequent, overlapping movement between Large Shelf 4, Area 5, and the shelving corridor (E14), repeatedly passing along the robot’s route. This results in both workers frequently occupying or crossing the robot’s path during its transport, minimizing the average distance between robot and workers due to dense, shared activity within the route’s corridor. All movement arises directly from legitimate workflow needs—receiving, sorting, quality-checking, and replenishing—resulting in constant, close proximity between the robot and the two workers without any intentional interference.

scenario_1.summary: During a high-turnover outbound operation with double quality control, Worker 1 performs rapid, repeated picking runs from Large Shelf 4 to Area 4 for order staging, while Worker 2 conducts quality checks at Area 4 and immediately relocates passed items to Shelf 2 or Shelf 3. Items failing audit are redirected by Worker 2 to Area 2 or back to Large Shelf 4. Both workers thus continuously traverse and re-traverse the core corridor—the exact route taken by the robot—as they pick, stage, inspect, and shuttle items between operational and storage zones. All movement arises from workflow necessity: dual handling, audit-and-repair cycles, and batch staging. This results in frequent, often simultaneous presence of both workers on or directly beside the robot’s fixed transport path from M21 to E14, yielding the smallest possible average robot-to-human distance by maximizing shared, overlapping activity within the robot’s navigation corridor, fully driven by the operational demands of complex outbound fulfillment and quality control.

scenario_2.summary: During an intensive biannual inventory count and live condition audit, two workers are assigned to physically audit all shelves and operational buffer areas along the robot's fixed route from M21 to E14. Worker 1 starts at Large Shelf 4 and audits all even-numbered shelves and adjacent areas northbound, immediately returning to Large Shelf 4 to restock any missing or damaged items and retracing their steps as needed. Worker 2 starts at Shelf 1, audits all odd-numbered shelves and buffer zones southbound, also retrieving all necessary restock materials from Large Shelf 4 whenever discrepancies are detected. Both workers crisscross the same robot corridor (M21–E14) multiple times, often in parallel, repeatedly passing each other and the robot as shelf errors, miscounts, or inventory damage force frequent, unpredictable returns to the large shelf. Audits, checks, and restocks are unsynchronized, causing dense, random overlapping activity along the robot's path. This constant movement in, out of, and along the robot’s entire route ensures that, throughout the operation, the robot maintains a minimum average distance from both workers, with much of its journey occurring within arm’s reach of at least one human. All proximity and environmental influences on the robot result solely from legitimate stock audit, retrieval, and restocking process requirements.

scenario_3.summary: During a surge in reverse logistics and damage returns processing, Worker 1 frequently shuttles returned and damaged goods from Large Shelf 4 to Area 1 for inspection, using the core warehouse corridor that precisely matches the robot’s fixed route (M21–E14). Worker 2 inspects items at Area 1, then rapidly alternates between moving restockable items to Shelf 2 or Shelf 3 (via E14/F14/F15) and transferring waste items to the Waste Area, both via pathways that directly overlap with or abut the robot’s waypoints. Intense, high-volume staging creates near-constant movement and physical overlap between the two workers in the main transport lanes, especially at Area 1 and adjacent shelves. This operational necessity—real-time triage, shared use of bottleneck areas, and parallel transport—results in the robot almost always traveling in close proximity to one or both workers, yielding a minimal average distance to the nearest human throughout its task. All proximity arises naturally as a consequence of the stepwise, high-intensity triage and restock workflow, without intentional positioning.

scenario_4.summary: In parallel urgent cycle-counting and live dispatch prep, Worker 1 audits inventory from Large Shelf 4 up through all major storage and operational areas along the warehouse central corridor (M21 to E14), physically checking and instantly correcting any slotting errors, requiring repeated, bi-directional travel along and across the robot’s exact route. Worker 2 simultaneously assembles outgoing dispatches at Area 5, repeatedly moving up and down the same corridor to pick inventory from Large Shelf 4, operational zones, and Shelves 2 and 3, instantly retrieving, correcting, or re-picking items on-the-fly upon detecting shortages or pick errors. Both workers’ unsynchronized, urgent operations cause them to continuously occupy, traverse, and overlap within the robot’s navigation corridor, frequently crisscrossing, paralleling, or converging at exactly the waypoints traversed by the robot. All proximity arises directly from operational necessity—the need for live correction, urgent slotting, and synchronized staging—resulting in the robot maintaining the smallest possible average distance to the workers throughout its task, with persistent near-contact due to task-driven congestion and workflow overlap.

scenario_5.summary: During a dual-mode warehouse operation, one worker executes rapid cross-docking of inbound items from Large Shelf 4 to Area 3 for staging, then immediately transfers sorted goods to Shelf 2 and Shelf 3 using the robot’s full corridor route (M21 → E14). Meanwhile, a second worker retrieves defective goods from Shelf 2 and Shelf 3, transports them to Area 2 for rework, and subsequently merges repaired items into Area 3 alongside new incomings. The two workers’ roles are operationally distinct but mutually dependent, repeatedly causing both to converge on, traverse, and share all key choke points—the entire robot path, with extreme focus at Area 3 and the shelving corridor. Their independent yet tightly interlocked activities require constant shuttling, concurrent staging, handoffs, and resource sharing on the exact corridor used by the robot, ensuring the smallest possible average distance between the robot and human workers as an authentic outcome of live cross-docking, defect rework, and buffer integration.

scenario_6.summary: A simultaneous hazardous material segregation (HMS) event and high-frequency, urgent outbound batch staging forces two workers into closely overlapping activity along the robot’s fixed warehouse route (M21 to E14). Worker 1 repeatedly removes flagged hazardous goods from Large Shelf 4 and Area 5, conveying them to the Waste Area, but must frequently stage these in Area 2 when the Waste Area is briefly blocked. Worker 2 picks, groups, and re-audits outgoing items from Shelf 3, Area 4, and Area 5, returning to correct errors or replenish items via the same corridor, sometimes using Area 2 as overflow buffer. Both workers undertake independent, asynchronous shuttling, with frequent crossings, mutual delays, and shared use of Area 2, leading to dense human activity precisely along and adjacent to the robot’s navigation waypoints. Their legitimate, urgent tasks require frequent stops and close movement on the robot’s route. The robot, moving autonomously and reacting only to physical environmental changes, is almost always in minimal proximity to at least one worker due to persistent corridor congestion, shared buffer use, and high activity around the robot’s path.

scenario_7.summary: During an urgent, compliance-driven expiry stock rotation, Worker 1 systematically removes soon-to-expire products from Large Shelf 4 (starting near M21), delivering them via the main central corridor (M21–E14) to Shelf 2 and Shelf 3 for fast-track outbound batching, and staging any items already past expiry at Area 2 for QA before transporting them to the Waste Area. Meanwhile, Worker 2, tasked with assembling outbound orders under FIFO/expiry batching rules, continuously shuttles between Shelf 2/3 (E14 area), Areas 4 and 5 (for staging and QA), and Area 2 whenever further QA/triage is required, using exactly the same corridor as the robot’s fixed route. Due to the time-critical nature of compliance and outbound shipping, both workers independently and repeatedly traverse, occupy, or work directly adjacent to the robot’s entire path (including at bottlenecks like Shelf 2/3, Area 2, and staging areas). All movement and proximity arises solely from legitimate expiry management and outbound workflow needs, which, due to process design and layout, reliably minimize the robot’s average distance to the closest worker throughout execution.

scenario_8.summary: A dual-stage, high-intensity kitting and de-kitting surge forces two workers to engage in continuous, spatially intertwined workflows. Worker 1 receives mixed-return kits at Area 5, rapidly de-kitting and sorting components, regularly shuttling usable parts through staging zones (Areas 3 and 4) to both Large Shelf 4 (for bulk restock) and Shelf 2/3 (for high-turnover pieces), and moving defectives to waste. Simultaneously, Worker 2 retrieves bulk kit components from Large Shelf 4, temporarily stages or pre-assembles items alongside Worker 1 at Areas 2, 3, and 4, then moves kits to Shelf 2 or Shelf 3 for order fulfillment, constantly looping back for missing or swapped parts. The process demands frequent, unsynchronized crossing, parallel movement, and shared occupancy along the robot’s fixed route from M21 to E14—especially through the open buffer and inspection corridor. The necessity for repeated multi-point handoffs, overlapping staging, and component swaps, combined with high volume and tight timing, ensures both workers remain almost always in or near the exact corridor the robot traverses, producing minimal average distance between the robot and humans. This pattern arises entirely from normal, urgent warehouse kitting/returns operations with zero intentional positioning, and represents a fundamentally different, multi-stage, relay-and-overlap workflow from any previously described scenario.

scenario_9.summary: Facing a sudden large-scale bin error and inventory misplacement event, the warehouse triggers a dynamic, live rebalancing and item-level repair operation. Worker 1 starts at Shelves 2 and 3 (E14 area), extracting misplaced or problem goods, moving down the robot’s fixed corridor toward Large Shelf 4 (M21), but stopping at Areas 3 and 4 to instantly check and fix faults en route. Repaired or relabeled items go on to Large Shelf 4, while unsorted ones loop through the buffer until corrected. Worker 2 begins at Large Shelf 4, transferring repaired or ready stock back up the corridor to Shelves 2 and 3, stopping at mid-corridor buffers for quick quality insertions and label checks. Both frequently return along the corridor after completing micro-tasks, causing dense, bidirectional, item-by-item convergence and congestion along every major waypoint and especially at bottlenecks (Areas 3/4). The robot, following its fixed M21→E14 path, continuously finds one or both workers immediately ahead, behind, or beside it—at random intervals due to genuine, unsynchronized inventory task flows—ensuring minimized average distance to the nearest person as a true consequence of urgent, high-activity, real-world stock and condition adjustment demands.
